DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese President Xi said the economic situation is good at the moment but added it faces deep and complicated changes. (Xinhua)

New Zealand Performance of Services Index (Dec) 53.0 (Prev. 53.5). (Newswires)


UK/EU

UK PM May said the right way to rule out a no deal is for the house to approve a deal and that the EU is unlikely to extend Article 50 without UK having a plan, while she is to hold further Brexit meetings this week and acknowledged their approach has changed since the first vote. Furthermore, UK PM May said a 2nd referendum could strengthen the hands of nationalists and doesn't believe there is a majority for one, while she added the UK will not reopen the Belfast agreement and that she is exploring the nature of any movement on the backstop that would secure the support of Parliament. (Newswires)

Conservative Party lawmaker Rudd warned PM May she could face dozens of ministerial resignations next week if Tory MPs are banned from voting for a plan that helps stop a no-deal Brexit. (Newswires)

EU Chief Negotiator Barnier said the Withdrawal Agreement including the Irish backstop, is “the best deal possible” for the UK in the Brexit negotiations, while he also dismissed reports of a bilateral arrangement between the UK and Ireland. (RTE)

Poland's Foreign Minister suggested the Irish backstop should be limited to five years, although Irish Deputy PM Coveney stated that the Withdrawal Agreement is not up for renegotiation and dismissed the call by the Polish Foreign Minister for a five-year limit on the backstop as not reflecting the EU position. (Newswires/RTE)

Cross-Channel freight trade 'could drop by 87%' under 'no-deal' Brexit according to reports which cited documents from the Border Force showing freight trade may operate at as little as 13% of its current capacity for 6 months. (Sky)


COMMODITIES

Saudi Arabia crude output rose by 0.451mln BPD in November and exports rose to 8.235mln BPD from 7.700mln BPD, according to JODI data. (Newswires)
 

US

IMF maintained US growth forecasts for 2019 at 2.5% and for 2020 at 1.8%, while it cut Euro-area growth forecasts for 2019 to 1.6% from 1.9% and cuts global growth forecasts for 2019 to 3.5% and for 2020 to 3.6%. (Newswires)


MARKET RECAP

US markets were closed for Martin Luther King Jr. Day, while European equities were lacklustre amid the absence of US participants and following the slew of Chinese data in which annual GDP declined to the slowest pace of growth in 28 years as expected.

subject: ICSG: World refined copper market in 15,000 T deficit in October 2018
RANsquawk Early US Market Wrap - 21st January 2019 - UK PM May offers “Plan B” to Parliament
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.


* REAR VIEW: UK PM May sticks to her plan & reaches out to Parliament for next step, IMF cuts global growth forecasts, US Markets closed due to Martin Luther King Day.

* AHEAD: UK Jobs Report, German ZEW Economic Sentiment & Current Conditions, US Existing Homes Sales, New Zealand CPI, Earnings from IBM, JNJ, UTX, HAL, PLD.

*  BREXIT: UK PM May presented her so-called ‘Plan B’ (which seems suspiciously like Plan A, commentators said) to Parliament on Monday, after her deal was widely rejected last week. The PM defended her position once again and acknowledged that the government’s approach has changed since the first vote. She warned that the only two ways to rule out a no deal scenario are to either extend Article 50, which would betray the results of the referendum as it would mean revoking the decision of the UK leaving the EU, or return to Brussels and renegotiate a deal which ensures an ordinarily exit from the block. She also appeared sceptical over the existence in Parliament of majority for a second referendum and warned that this option could strengthen the hands of nationalists. May made clear that the government will not reopen the Good Friday Agreement and she will seek input from Parliament and voices outside the government on the next phase of negotiations. During her initial statement, she scrapped the GBP 65 application fee for EU citizens to register in Britain. Looking ahead, a number of amendments are expected to be tabled between now and next Tuesday 29 January which will be selected by the Speaker and voted on by the Commons on that date. So far, the Cooper and the Grive amendments have been put forward; the former is aimed at giving Parliament power to extend Article 50 while the latter gives parliament the power to hold “indicative votes” on Brexit options (such as a Norway or Canada-style). 

* IMF cut global growth forecasts for 2019 to 3.5% and for 2020 to 3.6% as well as Euro-area growth forecasts for 2019 to 1.6% from 1.9%. However, it maintained US growth forecasts for 2019 at 2.5% and for 2020 at 1.8%. The IMF highlighted that risks to global growth have tilted to the downside and further escalation of trade tensions remains a key source of risk to outlook. A top economist noted that China growth is slowing as expected, though nothing dramatic is happening at this point; he highlighted that tax cuts and loosening of RRR cushioned the impact of tariffs and therefore their forecasts for China remain unchanged.

* GEOPOLITICS: Turkish President Erdogan said that he and US President Trump will take measures on steel import tariffs from Turkey.

* DXY: Further advances for the buck and on course to notch a 5th consecutive session of gains supported by the release of IMF’s global growth outlook in which forecasts were cut while citing further downside risks due to trade tensions. As investors sought the Dollar amidst thinned liquidity and trade woes, DXY pushed higher to an intraday peak of 96.440 (vs. low 96.200) ahead of the psychological 96.500 and its 50 DMA at 96.600. The index then consolidated just above 96.300 following PM May’s statement to Parliament.

* GBP, EUR: Cable remained within an intraday range of 1.2830-2910 as PM May’s statement failed to provide anything substantially new in addressing The House of Commons. Sterling showed some initial weakness after the PM announced the EU is unlikely to extend Article 50 without the UK having a plan settled. Nonetheless cable pushed towards the top end of the range, around 1.2900, after PM May stressed the only way to rule out a no deal is to find an agreement. She also reached out to Parliament and voices outside the government for consultations on negotiating a mandate for the next phase. Meanwhile, the EUR succumbed to the firmer buck as EUR/USD gave up earlier gains to trade flat on the day and closer to the bottom of a 1.1360-1400 range, below its 50 DMA at 1.1379.

* AUD, NZD, CAD: The trade-sensitive Aussie and Kiwi remain on the backfoot following IMF’s global growth downgrade alongside a firmer greenback as both currencies hovered near the bottom of today’s intraday range vs. the buck. AUD/USD breached its 100 DMA at 0.7173 and temporary slid further below 0.7150 to a session low of 0.7142. In regard to the Kiwi underperformance, Citi FX notes that the recent downside is “probably more a function of a position flush-out than it is any shifts in underlying prospects”, NZD/USD receded further below the 0.6750 level printed session lows just under 0.6720 ahead of the psychological 0.6700 and its 100 DMA at 0.6685. Elsewhere, the Loonie failed to gain impetus from the rising oil prices and yielded to the stronger Dollar with USD/CAD reclaiming the 1.3300 handle to the upside, but then failing to sustain that level sitting around 1.3290 in an intraday range of 1.3250-3317 ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.3341.

* JPY, CHF: A relatively docile day for the for the Yen following initial upside from disappointing Chinese growth numbers while USD/JPY traded within a tight 109.50-80 range while the absence of US participants drained liquidity. Elsewhere the Franc remained weak with stand-out news flow to affect the Swiss currency, EUR/CHF stabilised nearer to the top of a 1.1300-1.1350 range and similarly USD/CHF closer the top of the intraday range with speculation of potential SNB intervention taking place.

subject: FX Wrap: G10 braces for another Dollar dominant day ahead of Brexit plan B
content:
DXY – Further advances for the buck and on course to notch a 5th consecutive session of gains supported by the release of IMF’s global growth outlook in which forecasts were cut while citing further downside risks due to trade tensions. As investors sought the Dollar amidst thinned liquidity and trade woes, DXY pushed higher to an intraday peak of 96.440 (vs. low 96.200) ahead of the psychological 96.500 and its 50 DMA at 96.600.

GBP, EUR – The Pound is poised to end the day little changed as earlier upside was erased on the back of a rising buck, while PM May’s statement is yet to provide the Sterling with a clear direction, though not much is expected in way of a realistic and timely strategy. The Premier is scheduled to deliver her statement at 15:30 GMT with focus on any amendments tabled by MPs amid weekend reports that MPs will attempt to stop a no-deal scenarios post-statement. Two amendments to be aware of are the Cooper and Grieve amendments, the former is aimed at giving parliament power to extend Article 50 while the latter gives parliament the power to hold “indicative votes” on Brexit options (such as a Norway or Canada-style).  Cable remained tentative below its 100 DMA at 1.2868 and within an intraday range of 1.2830-2900. Meanwhile, the EUR succumbed to the firmer buck as EUR/USD gave up earlier gains to trade flat on the day and closer to the bottom of a 1.1360-1400 range, below its 50 DMA at 1.1379.

AUD, NZD, CAD – The trade-sensitive Aussie and Kiwi remain on the backfoot following IMF’s global growth downgrade alongside a firmer greenback as both currencies hovered near the bottom of today’s intraday range vs. the buck. AUD/USD breached its 100 DMA at 0.7173 and slid further below 0.7150 to a session low of 0.7142. In regard to the Kiwi underperformance, Citi FX notes that the recent downside is “probably more a function of a position flush-out than it is any shifts in underlying prospects”, NZD/USD receded further below the 0.6750 level printed session lows just under 0.6720 ahead of the psychological 0.6700 and its 100 DMA at 0.6685. Elsewhere, the Loonie failed to gain impetus from the rising oil prices and yielded to the stronger Dollar with USD/CAD reclaiming the 1.3300 handle to the upside in an intraday range of 1.3250-3317 ahead of its 50 DMA at 1.3341.

JPY, CHF – A relatively docile day for the for the Yen following initial upside from disappointing Chinese growth numbers while USD/JPY traded within a tight 109.50-80 range while the absence of US participants drained liquidity. Elsewhere the Franc remained weak with stand-out news flow to affect the Swiss currency, EUR/CHF stabilised nearer to the top of a 1.1300-1.1350 range and similarly USD/CHF closer the top of the intraday range with speculation of potential SNB intervention taking place.

RANsquawk EU Mid Session: Subdued session as Sterling eyes May’s scheme - 21st January 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

Major European equities are mostly in the red [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.2%] as sentiment is dictated by China’s 2018 GDP printing, as expected, the slowest growth in 28 years. FTSE MIB (-0.6%) is the underperforming index, weighed on by Telecom Italia (-1.9%) after the Co’s proposal to confer all network assets into a separate company has been opposed by the communications regulator. Meanwhile, UK’s FTSE 100 (+0.3%) outperforms on currency effects and as the Pound awaits PM May’s Brexit “Plan B”. Sectors are similarly in the red, with underperformance seen in Telecom names; where the aforementioned Telecom Italia is amongst those weighing on the sector. Other notable movers include William Hill (-2.6%) after the Co. state their full year operating profit for 2018 is expected to decrease from 2017’s level. Separately, Henkel (-5.3%) are towards the bottom of the Stoxx 600 after guiding FY19 EPS lower to mid-single digits.

FX

DXY – Little changed and closer to the top of a 96.200-380 range following a relatively rangebound Asia-Pac session, with little reaction to the confirmation by USTR Lightihzer regarding little progress in intellectual property issues in US-Sino trade talks, while US President Trump dismissed the WSJ report about US mulling to lift China tariffs to move forward dialogue. Liquidity in the markets will likely be thin as US participants are away on MLK day, while State-side data remains scarce as the US government has been shut for almost a month.

GBP, EUR – More angst for the Pound as PM May heads to the Commons later (around 15:30 GMT) to pitch her so-called “Plan B” with little expected in regard to a realistic strategy. Downing Street denied weekend reports that the Premier is looking to tweak the Good Friday agreement with Ireland to break the Brexit deadlock, while the Irish European Foreign Affairs Minister stated Ireland will not take part in bilateral talks and dialogue between EU and the UK, in turn pouring cold water on the Handelsblatt report from last week that the EU are ready to make further concessions on the backstop if the initiative comes from Ireland. Going back to May’s statement, there were reports over the weekend that MPs are to ambush the Premier with amendments aimed at stopping a no-deal scenario. Two amendments to be aware of are the Cooper and Grieve amendments, the former is aimed at giving parliament power to extend Article 50 while the latter gives parliament the power to hold “indicative votes” on Brexit options (such as a Norway or Canada-style).  GBP/USD current resides nearer to the bottom of a 1.2831-1.2900 range, below its 100 DMA at 1.2891 and around its 200 HMA at 1.2844. Meanwhile, the EUR remains firmer, albeit marginally as EUR/USD straddles around its 50 DMA at 1.1379 and closer to the middle of a 1.1361-1.1400 range ahead of the ECB interest rate decision on Thursday, while EUR 1.2bln in option expiries rest at strike 1.1400 for today’s NY cut.

JPY, CHF – Mixed trade for the “safe-haven” currencies with the Yen slightly firmer upon the release of Chinese GDP which printed the slowest annual growth in almost three-decades, though this was widely expected by analysts amid the ongoing US-China trade disputes. USD/JPY resides in the middle of a 109.50-80 range, while the absence of US participants will drain liquidity. Elsewhere, further suspicious activity in the weakening Franc as EUR/CHF stabilises nearer to the top of a 1.1300-1.1350 range and similarly USD/CHF closer the top of the intraday range with speculation of potential SNB intervention taking place.

CAD, NZD – The Kiwi underperforms in the G10 FX space as the currency is poised for its 6th consecutive session of losses amidst the backdrop of a global growth slowdown. NZD/USD extends losses below 0.6750 ahead of tomorrow’s NZ inflation release. Elsewhere, the Loonie is also on the backfoot as the decline in oil pressures the Canadian currency as USD/CAD breached its 50, 100 and 200 HMA’s to the upside to settle just under 1.3290.

FIXED INCOME

Gilt futures have kicked off the week on the front foot and outperform their peers ahead of PM May’s amendable Brexit Plan B presentation, with Ireland refusing bilateral negotiations and speculation abound that the PM has abandoned cross-party efforts and has instead laid her focus on deal-making with Brussels. The 10-year UK benchmark trades with gains of over 30 ticks and is in close proximity to session highs of 122.81 as speculation also continues to mount about the possibility of an Article 50 extension, a move the Government has refused to rule out (yet).

German 10-year futures underperform their UK counterparts but are in the green by just under 10 ticks. This comes after Germany posted softer than expected PPI figures. On a technical standpoint 10-year Bund traders are eyeing the 164.34 January 18th high as the next level to the upside as resistance. In the periphery, Italian 10-year futures are the European underperformer and are languishing at session lows with losses of over 30 ticks.

Over in the US, treasury futures are in the green, albeit by a shade, after little reported progress was made on US-China IP talks with action in Treasuries likely to be muted by MLK day. With electronic markets opening for a shortened session, little event risk is ahead today besides trade and Government shutdown updates as the data slate remains bare.

COMMODITIES 

Brent (-0.1%) and WTI (Unch%) recouped most of the initial losses, though prices remain below USD 63/bbl and USD 54/bbl; as the risk tone is directed by the slowest GDP growth in 28 years from China. Separately, China produced 3.86mln BPD for December which is a 2.85% increase Y/Y; however, 2018 domestic output decreased to 3.8mln BPD vs. Prev. 3.85mln BPD. Friday’s Baker Hughes Rig Count showed total decreased by 25 to 1050; with oil rigs decreasing by 21 to the lowest level in since May 2018.

Gold (-0.2%) is in the red but trading within a narrow USD 4/oz range, largely due to a lack of catalyst in the dollar as it is a US market holiday. Elsewhere, China’s primary aluminium output increased for the second month to a record in high in December of over 3mln tonnes; in contrast China’s daily average steel output in December fell to the lowest level since March, due to weaker profit margins.

subject: FX Morning Colour: Docile Dollar on MLK day while Sterling awaits May’s plan
content:
DXY – Little changed and closer to the top of a 96.200-380 range following a relatively rangebound Asia-Pac session, with little reaction to the confirmation by USTR Lightihzer regarding little progress in intellectual property issues in US-Sino trade talks, while US President Trump dismissed the WSJ report about US mulling to lift China tariffs to move forward dialogue. Liquidity in the markets will likely be thin as US participants are away on MLK day, while State-side data remains scarce as the US government has been shut for almost a month.

GBP, EUR – More angst for the Pound as PM May heads to the Commons later (around 15:30 GMT) to pitch her so-called “Plan B” with little expected in regard to a realistic strategy. Downing Street denied weekend reports that the Premier is looking to tweak the Good Friday agreement with Ireland to break the Brexit deadlock, while the Irish European Foreign Affairs Minister stated Ireland will not take part in bilateral talks and dialogue between EU and the UK, in turn pouring cold water on the Handelsblatt report from last week that the EU are ready to make further concessions on the backstop if the initiative comes from Ireland. Going back to May’s statement, there were reports over the weekend that MPs are to ambush the Premier with amendments aimed at stopping a no-deal scenario. Two amendments to be aware of are the Cooper and Grieve amendments, the former is aimed at giving parliament power to extend Article 50 while the latter gives parliament the power to hold “indicative votes” on Brexit options (such as a Norway or Canada-style).  GBP/USD current resides nearer to the bottom of a 1.2831-1.2900 range, below its 100 DMA at 1.2891 and around its 200 HMA at 1.2844. Meanwhile, the EUR remains firmer, albeit marginally as EUR/USD straddles around its 50 DMA at 1.1379 and closer to the middle of a 1.1361-1.1400 range ahead of the ECB interest rate decision on Thursday, while EUR 1.2bln in option expiries rest at strike 1.1400 for today’s NY cut.

JPY, CHF – Mixed trade for the “safe-haven” currencies with the Yen slightly firmer upon the release of Chinese GDP which printed the slowest annual growth in almost three-decades, though this was widely expected by analysts amid the ongoing US-China trade disputes. USD/JPY resides in the middle of a 109.50-80 range, while the absence of US participants will drain liquidity. Elsewhere, further suspicious activity in the weakening Franc as EUR/CHF stabilises nearer to the top of a 1.1300-1.1350 range and similarly USD/CHF closer the top of the intraday range with speculation of potential SNB intervention taking place.

CAD, NZD – The Kiwi underperforms in the G10 FX space as the currency is poised for its 6th consecutive session of losses amidst the backdrop of a global growth slowdown. NZD/USD extends losses below 0.6750 ahead of tomorrow’s NZ inflation release. Elsewhere, the Loonie is also on the backfoot as the decline in oil pressures the Canadian currency as USD/CAD breached its 50, 100 and 200 HMA’s to the upside to settle just under 1.3290.

content:
Gilt futures have kicked off the week on the front foot and outperform their peers ahead of PM May’s amendable Brexit Plan B presentation, with Ireland refusing bilateral negotiations and speculation abound that the PM has abandoned cross-party efforts and has instead laid her focus on deal-making with Brussels. The 10-year UK benchmark trades with gains of over 30 ticks and is in close proximity to session highs of 122.78 as speculation also continues to mount about the possibility of an Article 50 extension, a move the Government has refused to rule out (yet).

German 10-year futures underperform their UK counterparts but are in the green by about 10 ticks. This comes after Germany posted softer than expected PPI figures and ahead of the Bundesbank monthly report later in the day. On a technical standpoint 10-year Bund traders are eyeing the 164.34 January 18th high as the next level to the upside as resistance. In the periphery, Italian 10-year futures are the European underperformer and are languishing at session lows with losses of over 20 ticks.

Over in the US, treasury futures are in the green, albeit by a shade, after little reported progress was made on US-China IP talks with action in Treasuries likely to be muted by MLK day. With electronic markets opening for a shortened session, little event risk is ahead today besides trade and Government shutdown updates as the data slate remains bare.

European equity movers this morning: Casino (CO FP) +1.3%; Meggit (MGGT LN) +0.9%; Henkel (HEN GY) -4.7%; Alstom (ALO FP) -2.0%; Hammerson (HMSO LN) -1.7%; William Hill (WMH LN) -1.0%; Telecom Italia (TIT IM) -0.8%
Option expiries of note for today's NY cut
Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
ADP (ADP FP) – CEO of Vinci (DG FP) has confirmed interest in the Co., adding it would be coherent with their strategy. (Newswires) 

Sandvik (SAND SS) – Q4 Adj. operating profit SEK 4.71bln vs. Exp. SEK 4.70bln. Q4 order intake SEK 25.6bln vs. Exp. SEK 25.4bln. Adj. operating margin 18.1% vs. Exp. 18.3%. Co. dividend is seen at SEK 4.25. (Newswires)

William Hill (WMH LN) – FY adjusted operating profit for 2018 from continuing operations is expected GBP 234mln, down from 2017. FY underlying operating profit +4% Y/Y. State the US business roughly broke even in 2018 after allowing for expansion costs. (Newswires)

Meggit (MGGT LN) – Co. sign a 10-year USD 750mln contract with Pratt & Whitney for the continued supply of advanced engine composites for F135 and F119. (Newswires)

Just Eat (JE/ LN) – Peter Plumb is stepping down as CEO and director; search for a replacement to begin immediately. FY 2019 revenue expected in GBP 1-1.1bln range. FY 2019 underlying EBITDA expected in GBP 172-174mln range. (Newswires)

GlaxoSmithKline (GSK LN) – Philip Hampton to step down as non-executive chairman, board has begun to process to appoint a new chairman. (Newswires)

EDF (EDF FP) – Co. are to begin further tests on faulty weldings at their Flamanville nuclear reactor plant. (Newswires)

Orange (ORA FP) - Co. are reportedly considering options to purchase Euskaltel; amount not disclosed. (Newswires)

Henkel (HEN GY) - Co. guides FY 19 EPS lower to mid-single digits and organic sales +2-4% Y/Y. Co. increased range for dibidend payout ratio. (Newswires)

BRENNTAG (BNRN GY) UPGRADED TO BUY AT GOLDMAN SACHS

UBS (UBSG SW) INITIATED WITH BUY AT COMMERZEBANK

DANONE (BN FP) INITIATED WITH BUY AT BAML

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

21st January 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets began the week higher as the region followed suit to the optimism seen last Friday amongst the US majors after reports China is to offer concessions to eliminate the US trade imbalance, but with gains capped as participants digested a slew of Chinese data including 2018 GDP which was at the slowest growth in 28 years as expected. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were both positive from the open as they benefitted from the US-China trade optimism, but then pulled-back from their highs heading into the Chinese data and after US Trade Representative Lighthizer noted there was little progress made with China regarding intellectual property theft. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) had a relatively tepid open on caution prior to the key data releases and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations, although Chinese markets later breathed a sigh of relief from the inline GDP numbers, as well as better than expected Industrial Production and Retail Sales data.

FTSE

Sainsbury’s (SBRY LN) – Court ruling indicates that the final regulatory verdict over the Co’s Asda takeover will be delayed until the end of April, from early March. (Newswires)

BHP (BHP LN) – Western Australia reported an audit claiming the Co. owes up to USD 215mln in underpaid royalties on iron ore shipments. (Newswires)

ITV (ITV LN) – Co. hopes to raise a minimum of GBP 150mln from the sale of its London South Bank HQ after purchasing the site from Coal Pension Nominees for GBP 56mln in 2013. (FT)

Unilever (ULVR LN) – Co., PepsiCo (PEP) and Kellogg (K) are reportedly in the running to purchase Carlyle Group’s (CG) Graze unit. (Newswires)

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. are in talks with China’s largest state-backed nuclear company in regard to supplying the power plant with equipment. (FT)

UK energy names – A record 5.8mln households switched energy suppliers last year ahead of the government price cap on bills which was expected to discourage switching. (The Times)

UK airline names – Airlines have been criticised for not warning customers that planes tickets could be cancels alongside invalid passports in a no-deal Brexit scenario. (The Times)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Ryanair (RYA LN) – Co. may slow fleet expectation and cut jobs as it looks for cost saving measures; as according to Irish Press. (Newswires)

RPC Group (RPC LN) – Deadline for Apollo Global Management to make a firm offer for the Co. has been extended to January 23rd. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

DAILY MAIL & GENERAL (DNGT LN) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT CITI

KINGFISHER (KGF LN) DOWNGRADED TO UNDERPERFORM FROM SECTOR PERFORM AT RBC

HAMMERSON (HMSO LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JPMORGAN CHASE

DAX

Daimler (DIA GY) – Co. are considering an extensive alliance with BMW (BMW GY) related to autonomous driving. Separately, Co. are panning to create a new assembly plant for their Mercedes-Benz cars in Egypt; with a local business partner. (Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY)/Alstom (ALO FP) – EU antitrust officials are intending to block the Co.’s rail tie-up, as according to reports. Separately, French Finance Minister Le Maire stated he would meet European Commissioner Vestager to reiterate France’s support for the proposed deal (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Kion Group (KGX GY) – Co. are planning to expand their US Summerville factory to avoid a 25% tariff set on forklift imports from China. (WSJ)

Scout24 (G24 GY) – Co. have rejected a USD 5.3bln takeover offer from Hellman & Friedman and Blackstone. (Newswires)

Rheinmetall (RHM GY) – Co. are planning to sue the German government due to their decision to stop all arms exports to Saudi Arabia after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi. (Spiegel Online)

BROKER MOVES

DEUTSCHE TELEKOM (DTE GY) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

FRAPORT (FRA GY) UPGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM SELL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

CAC

Renault (RNO FP) –  France is said to favour a merger between Nissan (7201 JT) and Renault although there were also reports that French Finance Minister Le Maire downplayed merger prospects. Separately, former Nissan chairman Ghosn has offered to use his Nissan shares as collateral, surrender his passport and be electronically tagged in a new bail request. (Newswires)

Airbus (AIR FP) – Co. reportedly received an order for 65 planes from Japan’s Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group (8316 JT). (Nikkei)

Engie (ENGI FP) – Co. are close to completing their disposal of 4 coal-fired plants for EUR 250mln, according to reports. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

Casino (CO FP) – Co. are to sell 6 hypermarkets in France for EUR 100.5mln; as part of them divesting assets to reduce debt. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

EIFFAGE (FGR FP) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM EQUAL WEIGHT AT BARCLAYS

KLEPIERRE (LI FP) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

AIR FRANCE (AF FP) UPGRADED TO OUTPERFORM FROM NEUTRAL AT DAVY

VALEO (FR FP) REITERATED OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

PAN EUROPE

Banca Monte de Paschi (BMPS IM)/Banca Carige (CRG IM) – Italian government are reportedly considering merging the troubled Co’s with healthier banks to prevent a banking crisis. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Co’s proposal to confer all network assets into a separate company, which would be fully controlled by the Co. has been opposed by communications regulator AGCOM; who sees no value in this. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

TOD’S (TOD IM) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT CITI

ASML (ASML NA) REITERATED OUTPERFORM AT CREDIT SUISSE

SMI

Roche (ROG SW) – US FDA has approved a biosimilar to the Co’s Herceptin, a breast cancer treatment. (Newswires)

ABB (ABBN SW) – Co’s CEO states the Co. may make further acquisitions in industrial automation and robotics areas. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

SPX +1.36% at 2672, NASDAQ +0.98% at 6785, DJI +1.41% at 24713. SECTORS: Energy +1.99%, Materials +1.76%, Industrials +1.97%, Cons Discretionary +1.32%, Cons Staples +1.26%, Healthcare +1.26%, Financials +1.76%, Tech +1.52%, Telecoms +0.53%, Utilities +0.28%.

subject: Downing Street has reportedly denied UK PM May's plans to change the Good Friday agreement to save her Brexit deal; according to PoliticsHome
content: • Click here for the article
analysis_details: • This comes amid earlier reports that UK PM May is reportedly considering amending Good Friday Agreement after failing again at attempt to negotiate a crossparty deal to break the Brexit deadlock.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 21st January 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets began the week higher as the region followed suit to the optimism seen last Friday amongst the US majors
  • Overnight data releases saw Chinese Q4 GDP print in-line with expectations, whilst retail sales and IP exceeded forecasts
  • US Trade Representative Lighthizer said US and China are making little progress regarding intellectual property issues
  • UK PM May halted the cross-party approach to Brexit last night as she informed her cabinet that she would focus on securing changes from Brussels
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK PM May tabling her amendable Brexit motion. Note US markets are closed for MLK Day

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets began the week higher as the region followed suit to the optimism seen last Friday amongst the US majors after reports China is to offer concessions to eliminate the US trade imbalance, but with gains capped as participants digested a slew of Chinese data including 2018 GDP which was at the slowest growth in 28 years as expected. ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were both positive from the open as they benefitted from the US-China trade optimism, but then pulled-back from their highs heading into the Chinese data and after US Trade Representative Lighthizer noted there was little progress made with China regarding intellectual property theft. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) had a relatively tepid open on caution prior to the key data releases and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations, although Chinese markets later breathed a sigh of relief from the inline GDP numbers, as well as better than expected Industrial Production and Retail Sales data. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded relatively flat with demand subdued amid the gains in riskier assets and with downside also limited by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs in maturities spread across the curve.
 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net drain of CNY 80bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.7774 (Prev. 6.7665)


Chinese GDP (Q4) Q/Q 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%). (Newswires)

Chinese GDP (Q4) Y/Y 6.4% vs. Exp. 6.4% (Prev. 6.5%)

Chinese GDP (2018) Y/Y 6.6% vs. Exp. 6.6% (Prev. 6.7%)

Chinese Industrial Output (Dec) Y/Y 5.7% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.4%)

Chinese Retail Sales (Dec) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.1% (Prev. 8.1%)

China stats bureau chief said China has ample room for macro policy adjustments and that China will cut more taxes as well as fees. (Newswires)

US President Trump stated there was a recent false report about lifting China tariffs, while he added trade talks are going well and a trade deal with China could very well happen. In separate news, it was also reported over the weekend that US President Trump’s Administration is said to be preparing an executive order that would restrict Chinese telecoms from operating in US. (Newswires)

US Trade Representative Lighthizer said US and China are making little progress regarding intellectual property issues, while Chinese officials denied IP theft and have asked US for proof. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

UK PM May held a conference call with the Cabinet to renew efforts to find acceptable changes to the backstop arrangement. However, the conversation was said to be light on specifics and a source also stated there were "no actual solutions" proposed during the call. (Guardian)

UK PM May halted the cross-party approach to Brexit last night as she informed her cabinet that she would focus on securing changes from Brussels designed to win over rebel Conservatives and the DUP. (Times) Labour leader Corbyn is reportedly likely to refrain from making fresh moves towards backing a second referendum until PM May’s “Plan B” is voted on at the end of the month. (The Guardian)

UK PM May is reportedly considering amending Good Friday Agreement after failing again at attempt to negotiate a cross-party deal to break the Brexit deadlock. The proposal could see a rewriting of the 1998 accord to assure Ireland that the UK is committed to no hard border on the island after the UK leaves the EU in March (Telegraph)

EU is reportedly split regarding how long UK should delay Brexit with some governments said to be calling for an extension of as long as a year, while some are against any extension. (Newswires)

UK’s Leave Means Leave is fundraising and plotting a campaign strategy in the belief that another referendum is now inevitable and Brexiteers have fallen behind pro-Remain groups in preparing for a fresh vote. (Telegraph)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Jan) M/M 0.4% (Prev. -1.5%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Jan) Y/Y 0.4% (Prev. 0.7%)

Fitch affirmed Austria at 'AA+'; outlook Positive and affirmed France at 'AA'; outlook stable, while S&P affirmed Grece at B+; outlook positive. (Newswires)


FX

FX markets struggled for firm direction with the DXY rangebound as the US celebrates the long-weekend due to Martin Luther King Jr. Day, while its major counterparts were mixed in which EUR/USD attempted to recover some of its recent losses and with GBP/USD lacklustre ahead of PM May’s ‘Plan B’ deadline today. Furthermore, it was reported that PM May is considering amending the Good Friday Agreement to break the deadlock and that she held a conference call with the Cabinet in an effort to find a solution to the backstop issue, although a source noted the conversation was light on specifics and that there were no actual solutions proposed during the call. Elsewhere, high-beta currencies and USD/JPY traded indecisive but found some brief support in the aftermath of the Chinese data deluge.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were indecisive overnight as participants digested the slew of Chinese data releases with WTI crude futures marginally supported to briefly above USD 54.00/bbl on relief as Chinese GDP printed inline with expectations, although upside was limited as the data also showed the slowest annual growth in 28 years. Elsewhere, gold traded flat and mirrored the similar lacklustre price action in the greenback amid the US holiday, while copper was slightly softer but held on to support around USD 2.70/lb.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (18/Jan): oil rigs down 21 at 852, nat gas down 4 at 198, total down 25 at 1050 (prev. 1075). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

White House said US President Trump is planning a second summit with North Korea at the end of February, while it added that the US continues to make progress with North Korea and that sanctions are to remain. In related news, US State Department said Secretary of State Pompeo and Special Representative Biegun "had a good discussion" with the North Korean Envoy on efforts for progress on commitments made at the Singapore summit. (Newswires)

Syrian air defences reportedly shot down several hostile targets according to SANA, while the Israel Military later confirmed it was conducting strikes on Iranian Qud Forces targets in Syria and warned Syria not to harm Israeli territory or forces. (Newswires)

US

Investors moved away from treasuries on Friday as sentiment improved on hopes that US and China are making progress in talks. Solid manufacturing output also placed downward pressure on the complex. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve where yields were higher by c.5 bps at settlement. The yield curve saw some modest bear flattening heading into the long weekend as US markets will remain closed on Monday. US T-note futures (H9) settled 11 ticks lower at 121-05+.

US President Trump reportedly made an offer on the shut down over the weekend that would provide “Dreamers” and Temporary Protection Status visa holders protection to stay in US for another 3 years in exchange for funding the Border Wall, although this was said to have been rejected by the Democrats. (Newswires)

US Special Counsel Mueller’s office said BuzzFeed report that alleged document showed President Trump told former lawyer Cohen to lie, are not accurate. (Newswires)

Fed's Daly (Non-Voter, Dovish) is reportedly leaning towards pausing on interest rate hikes for a while. (Washington Post)

subject: Riksbank’s Jansson says it was incorrect to raise rates at December meeting

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia began the week positive after reports of China trade concessions,  but with gains capped by China data deluge in which annual GDP printed its slowest in 28 years as expected

ASX 200 (+0.2%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.2%) were both positive from the open as they benefitted from the US-China trade optimism, but then pulled-back from their highs heading into the Chinese data and after US Trade Representative Lighthizer noted there was little progress made with China regarding intellectual property theft. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.4%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) had a relatively tepid open on caution prior to the key data releases and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations, although Chinese markets later breathed a sigh of relief from the inline GDP numbers, as well as better than expected Industrial Production and Retail Sales data. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded relatively flat with demand subdued amid the gains in riskier assets and with downside also limited by the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs in maturities spread across the curve.

PBoC Director of Monetary Policy Sun Guofeng says banks must support real economy and that PBoC will encourage market-based interest rate reform
Fitch says China onshore corporate bond defaults reached a record high last year
US probe into rigging of certain Treasury auctions has stalled amid lack of evidence, while it is unclear if the government will bring charges against the banks involved, according to NY Post
Nomura economist sees China GDP growth slowing to 6% for 2019
Thailand Imports (Dec) Y/Y -8.2% vs. Exp. 4.9% (Prev. 14.7%)
Thailand Exports (Dec) Y/Y -1.7% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. -1.0%)
Thailand Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 1.1bln vs. Exp. -1.0bln (Prev. -1.2bln)
Thailand Trade Balance (USD)(Dec) 1.1bln vs. Exp. -1.0bln (Prev. -1.2bln)
Thailand Imports (Dec) Y/Y -8.2% vs. Exp. 4.9% (Prev. 14.7%)
Thailand Exports (Dec) Y/Y -1.7% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. -1.0%)
Chinese Premier Li says important to stimulate market vitality to withstand downward pressure
PRE-MARKET INDIA STOCK NEWS: HDFC Bank (HDFCB IS) Q3 net rose 20.3% Y/Y to INR 55.6bln.
content:
Bharat Heavy Electricals (BHEL AT)
- Co. and Libcoin are in discussions on setting up a lithium ion battery Gigafactory in India. (Newswires)

HDFC Bank (HDFCB IS)
- Co. Q3 net rose 20.3% Y/Y to INR 55.6bln. (ET)

MindTree (MTCL IS)
- L&T Infotec (LTI IS) is reportedly interested in acquiring a stake in the Co. (Newswires)

Larsen & Toubro (LT IS)
- Co. planned share repurchase plan of INR 90bln was denied by SEBI. (ET)

Wipro (WPRO IS)

Other News
- RBI Governor Das was under fire over the central bank’s lack of independence amid expectations the central bank may transfer USD 5.7bln in dividends to the government to help dress up the government’s accounts before fiscal year-end and general elections. (FT)

subject: China stats bureau chief says China will cut more taxes and fees, adds will raise special bond quotas
China stats bureau chief says China has ample room for macro policy adjustments
Goldman Sachs says it now expects RBI to cut rates at meeting on February 7th vs. Prev. forecast for unchanged
ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia tracks Friday's Wall St gains on potential trade concessions by China, while region also digests China data deluge
content:
Asia equity markets are higher as the region follows suit to the optimism seen last Friday amongst the US majors after reports China is to offer concessions to eliminate the US trade imbalance, but with gains capped as participants digest a slew of Chinese data including 2018 GDP which was at the slowest growth in 28 years as expected. ASX 200 (+0.3%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.5%) were both positive from the open as they benefitted from the US-China trade optimism, but then pulled-back from their highs heading into the Chinese data and after US Trade Representative Lighthizer noted there was little progress made with China regarding intellectual property theft. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.8%) saw a relatively tepid start on tentativeness prior to the key releases and after the PBoC skipped liquidity operations, although later saw mild relief from the inline GDP numbers, as well as better than expected Industrial Production and Retail Sales data.

FX markets struggle for firm direction with the US celebrating the long-weekend due to Martin Luther King Jr. Day which has kept DXY rangebound above the 96.00 level, while its major counterparts are mixed with EUR/USD attempting to recover some of its recent losses and with GBP/USD marginally slipping past Friday’s lows ahead of PM May’s ‘Plan B’ deadline today. Furthermore, it was reported that PM May is considering amending the Good Friday Agreement to break the deadlock and that she held a conference call with the Cabinet in an effort to find a solution to the backstop issue, although a source noted the conversation was light on specifics and that there were no actual solutions proposed during the call. Elsewhere, high-beta currencies and USD/JPY trade indecisive although have found some mild solace in the aftermath of the Chinese data deluge.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are relatively flat with demand subdued amid the gains in riskier assets, although losses are stemmed and prices are off last week’s lows amid the BoJ’s presence in the market for JPY 1tln of JGBs with maturities across the curve.

Chinese GDP 2018 Y/Y 6.6% vs. Exp. 6.6% (Prev. 6.7%)
Chinese GDP (Q4) Q/Q 1.5% vs. Exp. 1.5% (Prev. 1.6%)
reaction_details:
- AUD/USD immediately moved higher by 26 pips to 0.7182 from 0.7156 but then pared half the move in the next minute.
- USD/JPY moved higher by 8 pips to 109.60 from 109.52.

PRE-MARKET CHINESE  STOCK NEWS: China is said to propose path to eliminating trade deficit with US; Chinese GDP, Industrial Production and Retail Sales data due for release
content:
Beijing Kangde Xin Composite Material (002450 CH)
- Securities regulators conducting investigation on allegations some funds were being used by major shareholders. (Newswires)

China Gas Holdings (384 HK)
- SK Gas is to sell 42.9mln shares in the Co. (Newswires)

China Mobile (941 HK)
- Co. December mobile net additions 3.0mln with total mobile subscribers at 925mln. (Newswires)

China Unicom (762 HK)
- Co. December mobile net additions 2.0mln with total mobile subscribers 315mln. (Newswires)

Haitong Securities (600837 CH)
- Co. reports prelim FY18 net CNY 5.2bln vs. Prev. CNY 8.6bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Sunac China Holdings (1918 HK)
- Co. acquires Beijing and Shanghai project valued at around CNY 12.6bln. (Newswires)

Railway
- China Railway executive said 2019 rail investments is seen likely to increase 6% Y/Y to a record CNY 850bln. (Newswires)

Telecoms
- US President Trump’s Administration is said to be preparing an executive order that would restrict Chinese telecoms from operating in US. (Newswires)

Other News
- China is reportedly to offer a path to eliminate US trade imbalance, according to sources which suggested that China is to offer a 6-year import boost exceeding USD 1tln, although US trade negotiators are said to be sceptical of the offer. (Newswires)
- US President Trump stated there was a recent false report about lifting China tariffs, while he added trade talks are going well and a trade deal with China could very well happen. (Newswires)
- China was said to begin anti-dumping probe on polysilicon from US and South Korea. (Newswires)
